column4: I have this concern, bassically I locked the root account with 'passwd -l' and made sure I was in the sudoers file right? problem is I have errors on my partition and am in urgent need of fsck repairs, but when I go into emergency mode it asks me for a root password which I don't have since the account is locked! know what I could do? without sacrificing a security concern that someone knows 'root' is my administrator account?
yes?
did you do an expert install ? or did you previously enable root ? by default it should be disabled
ok. but you get asked for a password on recovery mode?
or is the problem that you *don't* get asked for a password?
Yes, hmm could it be that I should remove a password before locking the account?
i haven't used 'passwd -l'; i'll check the man page in a moment. When I boot into recovery mode I go straight to a root prompt with no password check

Yeah the problem is I 'had' to use expert mode, apt-get setup freezes the install on my system, even in the newest breezy so expert was the only one that worked, but at the same time I'm trying to default things back to how they would have been if I didn't use expert.
fair enough. FWIW, here's my entry for 'root' in /etc/shadow: root:*:13072:0:99999:7:::
maybe try forcing your entry to be similar ('man shadow' says a * disables login)
Thanks for the advice, yes I don't have an * I'll go ahead and copy that shadow entry as a default incase I can't figure it out any other way.
i'd like to know why it asks for a password on recovery mode; let me know if you find out
Sure I'll go try some things and figure out how to default back to that value without having to do it the hard way and change shadow, then inform you.

For an expert setup the only way to return to the default sudo usage is to A: edit the sudoers file with 'visudo' as root and place your primary user account in there with all priveledges or 'user   ALL=(ALL) ALL', then edit the shadow file, put an * as root..
thanks. your system is working as desired now?
or rather an * in the second field.

Not really, I got single user and emergency mode to work fine, but there is something it won't let me do... unmount my root partition, I happen to know there are errors in the superblock.. but I can't unmount it even under emergency mode.
hmm. d'you have a live cd ?
I do, think it's the only option at this point?
well, i think it's probably the easiest
Well thanks again for the help, I'll got boot Damn Small Linux and fix the partition.
cool. good luck
